awd_titl_txt: South Dakota Working in STEM for Equity (SD-WISE): A System, Institutional, and Individual Level Approach to Policy Change
awd_abstract_narration:
The NSF Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks:  Institutions of Higher Education (PLAN-IHE) funding track is designed to expand the application of proven-successful gender-equity initiatives for STEM faculty through networked adaptation of a specific program or initiative.  Careful evaluation is expected to expand understanding of such initiatives across institutions and institution types.

This project will focus on producing policy changes to support gender equity and create culture change within the South Dakota state university system.  This project will include six institutions: South Dakota State University (SDSU), the University of South Dakota, South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, Northern State University, Dakota State University, and Black Hills State University.  This project has system wide leadership commitment and involves teams of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) faculty in the policy review and development.  The model, if successful, could be adapted to other higher education systems.  It is expected that this project will result in: evidence of effective top-down change mechanisms in higher education; amended or new policies that promote gender equity in STEM; and contributions to the research on processes for systemic change in higher education.

This project will test the proposition that the central establishment of equity policy and indicators at the system level is required not only to demonstrate improvement in diversity but to actualize it (Blackmore, 2011; Castilla, 2008; Kalev, Kelly and Dobbin, 2006).  Research from industry indicates the effectiveness of "top-down" change for increased gender equity.  By implementing and assessing this process in academia, new evidence and subsequent models for centralized change will be produced for use beyond this state system.  In this project, Scott's model (1987) of change is used to demonstrate that change is most effectively implemented through policy driven by a central authority.  The project will expand and assess understanding of the probability of gender equity improvement in higher education state systems through policy implementation by a centralized authority.  This work will also establish evidence for how centralized policies can change individual faculty assessment practices across a higher education system, linking the system and institutional level in Scott's theory of change.  In addition, this project will contribute to the knowledge base on how centralized policies can change individual norms in career planning and aspirations, linking the system, institutional, and individual level in Scott's theory of change.  This project builds on previous ADVANCE work at the University of Maryland in policy analysis, and work completed at Montana State University to solicit policy innovation. 

The ADVANCE PLAN program track supports projects that promote the adaptation and implementation of previously effective ADVANCE programs in new contexts and the testing of innovative strategies to promote the participation, success, and advancement of women in STEM academic careers.  PLAN projects also contribute to the knowledge base on gender equity in STEM academic careers.

por.por_cntn:
The SD-WISE project focused on place-based research to increase equity among faculty in the state?s six public institutions.  The six state institutions partnering in this grant provide a diversity of representation in the STEM disciplines and differing strengths in their curriculum and specializations.  Three of the six institutions (South Dakota State University, hereafter SDSU; University of South Dakota, hereafter USD; and the South Dakota School of Mines and Technology, hereafter SDSMT) are leaders in multiple STEM areas for Ph.D. study, and the remaining three institutions (Northern State University, hereafter NSU; Dakota State University, hereafter DSU; and Black Hills State University, hereafter BHSU) represent single disciplinary strength in STEM study at the graduate and undergraduate level.  Our inherent structural and curricular diversity have allowed us to expand knowledge on the impacts of system-level policy change in a variety of institutional environments.

SDSU (2020 enrollment 9,976 undergraduates, and 1,429 graduate students), USD (9,459 at the undergraduate and graduate level in 2020) and SDSMT (2020 graduate and undergraduate student enrollment 2,477) are the premier doctoral granting institutions in the state.

NSU (3,431 students in 2020) specializes in education technology, including graduate and undergraduate degrees in STEM science education. DSU (3,186 students in 2020) specializes in graduate and undergraduate degrees in computer science and technology. BHSU (3.608 students in 2020), in addition to programs in sciences, also supports the Center of Excellence in Mathematics and Science Education.

The research committee was comprised of 6 female faculty members (hereafter PLAN committee), each representing different STEM fields from each institution.  We also worked with representatives from the South Dakota Board of Regents (hereafter SDBOR) and created a Steering Committee for the grant work comprised of the six Provosts from each state institution.

The focus of the research was primarily social science based, and included a 5 year review of faculty salary trends across all institutions, a limited review of faculty evaluation documents, five surveys of faculty state-wide (three pertaining to faculty retention, two pertaining to campus climates and service obligations), and qualitative assessments of individual experiences in the SDBOR system.

Our findings illustrate the specific challenges for diverse faculty (i.e., gender, race and citizenship status) in predominately rural states in US higher education. The context often reflects consideration of state control, state and federal funding allocations for higher education, and general social support for higher education in the state context. 

Firstly, the PLAN committee conducted a survey of faculty policy prioritization to implement change. We found that, across all institutions, the highest priorities for policy change included salary equity, paid parental leave, and transparency in faculty evaluation and promotion and tenure outcomes.  These findings were not distinguished by gender, race, or citizenship status. Outcomes include the creation of an Automatic Stop-the-Clock for tenure policy for all faculty in the case of childbirth adoption.  The SDBOR also instituted a voluntary paid family leave policy, which incorporates use of accumulated sick days during an approved period.  Transparency in P&T processes is unable to be determined.

Secondly, two faculty surveys assessing campus climate and service workload were conducted.  The former was to ascertain the degree of inequity in faculty experience at the institutional and state-wide level, the latter to ascertain particulars of potential inequity in faculty assignments. We found that, in contrast to common social belief, that many STEM faculty trend more conservative and therefore less open to policy pertaining to gender equity. Further, despite female faculty being over-represented in lecturer roles overall, they were more likely to be assigned service obligations.

Thirdly, we conducted a comprehensive state-wide study of faculty salary trends from 2012 to 2020, particularly focusing on gender and citizenship inequities.  While citizenship played a limited role, we found that female faculty at all institutions were compensated less than their male counterparts both at the beginning and later in their careers (Liebl et al. 2021). The study controlled for rank, discipline and length of service, yet the outcome indicates that these trends by gender are consistent state-wide, although vary by institution. 

Fourthly, a survey was conducted examining retention rates for faculty by gender, and showed a disproportionate level for departure or other job search by female faculty (Eduful et al, 2021  unpublished dissertation to date).  It needs to be noted that this research took place prior to and during the COVID-19 crises, a particularly difficult time for higher education nation-wide.  Nonetheless, in keeping with previous findings, it appears that female faculty in the SDBOR system seek other opportunities, proportionately larger than their male counterparts. 

The challenges facing higher education in the political, social and rural context today are as polarized as our society.  The enduring outcome of our work is the continued attention by the PLAN committee to state-wide experience and change for gender equity.
